options.text: Well, combat is part of being in the military. Why don’t I pull together a list of scholarships you might be eligible for while you gather the information needed to apply for financial aid.
options.ending: This response provides the family with helpful resources, which we don't want to discourage! However, it doesn't dispel their myths about the military or encourage them to research all the options available for Dana to reach her post-secondary dream.

options.text: You do have to be okay with violence to join the military. But if you’re not willing to use scholarships, financial aid, or military benefits, I think you’re out of options. Would you like to explore careers that don’t require a college education?
options.ending: This response perpetuates the myths Dana has about the military. It also presents post-secondary options that are not in line with her career goals.

events.body: How should Mr. C respond?

options.text: Actually, 85% of military jobs do not involve direct combat. And after serving 3-8 years, most service members leverage their education and training for civilian careers. Only about 20% stay in the military until retirement.
options.ending: Well done! Click the button to move onto the next event.

options.text: Well, those are valid concerns. Dana didn’t seem interested in scholarships or financial aid, but maybe you can convince her. Here’s some information about those options.
options.ending: This response perpetuates the myths Dana has about the military. It also does not address her concerns about student debt.

options.text: I understand your concerns. Dana said she’s not interested in scholarships or financial aid either, so I think you’re out of options. Would you like me to provide some career exploration tools? Maybe you could help Dana choose a career that doesn’t require a college education.
